blocks.content: Wi-Fi hacking means testing the security of wireless networks. In naval style, it is like intercepting radio communication signals between ships to understand how secure their channel is. This is done only in labs or networks you own.

content: Find weak Wi-Fi passwords
Test Wi-Fi encryption strength
Capture handshake packets
Use controlled brute-force attacks in a lab

blocks.content: To crack a Wi-Fi password, we capture the WPA/WPA2 handshake and try passwords from a wordlist. In naval style, the handshake is like capturing the secret radio code exchanged between two friendly ships.

content: Step 1: Put Wi-Fi adapter in monitor mode
Step 2: Capture handshake packets
Step 3: Use a wordlist to guess the password
Command: airmon-ng start wlan0
Why: Enables monitor mode to capture Wi-Fi signals.
Command: airodump-ng wlan0mon
Why: Shows nearby Wi-Fi networks.
Command: airodump-ng --bssid TARGET_BSSID -c CHANNEL -w capture wlan0mon
Why: Captures the handshake from the target network.

blocks.content: After capturing the handshake, we use a wordlist to crack the password. This is done only on your own Wi-Fi or lab networks.

content: Command: aircrack-ng capture.cap -w wordlist.txt
Why: Tests each password from the wordlist to find the correct one.
If password is found: you see KEY FOUND!

blocks.content: A custom wordlist helps when you know personal details about your target network (lab scenario only). In naval style, it's like knowing the naming patterns used by a shipâ€™s crew.

content: Command: crunch 8 12 abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz -o mylist.txt
Why: Creates a wordlist of lengths 8 to 12 with given characters.
Command: cewl https://example.com -w website.txt
Why: Generates a wordlist from words found on a website.
Command: john --wordlist=passwords.txt --rules --stdout > mutated.txt
Why: Mutates simple passwords into stronger combinations.
